reviewText: A departure from the usual Homecoming concerts, this is a celebration of family, Homecoming Picnic 2008.  The picnic at the historic Fiddler's Grove in  Lebanon, Tennessee is all in the name of a family event.  You will hear how many speak just how much this concert/picnic  setting means to them, seeing friends who are like family.Many new singers are here along with a few of the old timers, like Russ Taff, Lynda Randle, Larry Ford, and Dottie Rambo "Mama Teaching Angels to Sing".  Dottie must have died shortly after in May 2008.  The Speer Family join in for a tribute to Brock Speer who died in 1999.  Ben Speer sings "I Was There When it Happened."Some performances that stood out for me were the Gaither Vocal Band singing a very beautiful song, "I Heard it First on the Radio".  I figured it was Gaither-written because I remember Bill talking about his experience listening to the gospel on the radioTurn Your Radio On;  and I like "He Pilots My Ship" with Buddy Mullins and "Farther Along" with Michael English.You will enjoy the rousing  "Sweetest Song I Know" lead by Mike Allen, Russ Taff, Ben Speer, Becky Isaacs, Johnny Minnick, Michael English and Jessy Dixon.  I especially enjoy "This Great Caravan Keeps on Rolling Along" and "I'm Living in Canaan Now."Other performances include:  Gordon Mote "Sweet Forgiveness";  TaRanda Green sings "Sky Full of Angels";  and two favorites, and Larry Ford leads for "Palms of Victory";  The Booth Brothers sing "Without the Lord";Highlight!Two of my favorite songs include, the very beautiful "Eastern Gate" sung by the Easters, and Jim Hill, who wrote and sings "What a Day That Will Be".Tanya Goodman Sykes sings "Look for Me"; and several join in for "I'm a Soldier"Harmonica player Buddy Greene plays "Gentle Shepherd/I Will Serve Thee and along with the Isaacs for "Sally Goodin/Wildwood Flower."  Newcomers The Hayes Family sing "Did You Ever Go Sailin".This is a fun Homecoming Series, casual without an audience and you get to meet some family members. This is fun! Inside pamphlet has lyrics.... Rizzo
summary: Family, Food, Music, Fun and a campfire!
Title: N/A

reviewText: What can you say other than wonderful music. I collect anything with The Gaither name on it. The best Gospel music you will ever listen to and watch. I have 35 videos and plan on getting everyone they have made. It amazing me how great their voices are and how they put their heart and soul in each performance.Don't miss out on the best music you will ever own.Thanks to Amazon and the seller.

reviewText: I ENJOYED SEEING A SUMMER SCENE.IT ALSO SHOWS SOME OF THE OLD TIMERS AS WELL AS SOME NEW SONGS BY THE YOUNGER SETS, AND SOME OF THE CHILDREN OF SOME OF THESE DEAR ONES. GUY PENRODS DAUGHTER IS ON IT .

reviewText: I have several of the Gaither's Homecoming series and really enjoy them.  This one did not disappoint me either.  Really like it!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I loved this DVD. It is filmed in Tennessee around a campfire, and it includes all of the Gaither friends and families.  GVB consists of Wes, Marshall, Guy, Michael, and Bill. Gordon Mote on keyboard. After watching this DVD I feel like I've just been among old friends and family of my own. Included is a look inside Linda Randle's motor home, and meeting her family. Bill mingles among all of the homecomers and reminisces about some old times with them. The bonus feature is extra special. The music on this DVD is second to none.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I can but marvel at the durability of Bill and Gloria Gaither. Keeping folks around, and making transitions as though they are simply meant to be, with a minimum of turmoil and a maximum of grace, cannot be as easy as it appears. Yet,here again these are not usual folks, but a special gift to those of us that are blessed -as I have been- by their fellowship in the grace that keeps us humble in our passion for the forgiveness Jesus taught. What we see are the results of labor and prayer, talent and stick-to-it-ive-ness. What I find perfect is the love they share. What I find that makes me feel like a part of it is their humanity and faith. What makes this all so beautiful is the music, the singing, and the songs.Homecoming Picnic was a good choice and is one of my more recent. I will say that the dear late Dottie Rambo was an admirable song writer; nonetheless, I shudder a bit when I hear her song. "Mama's Teaching Angels How to Sing." This song is on another DVD that I have, which makes two too many. Nonetheless, the Gaithers, Dottie, and The Isaacs remain sources of blessing. To them and all those who believe that God so loved the world, I am thankful. This world can seem so lopsided with variations of prejudice, dogma, confusion and drama, that it is sometimes hard to see a path, to recognize a truth, or to even believe in peace.So, I love these folks one and all, but I still  find that particular sentiment a rather ridiculous concept, apparently presented as something one should embrace.The other songs are fine. I especially like Ta Randa Green, Buddy Mullin, and -of course, The Booth Brothers. When I learned that the latter had a song on this video, I opted to buy it, and I am pleased that I did. It is a worthwhile addition.
summary: Another addition to my library of Gaither music.
